Advanced Vocabulary - Page 3

Advanced

Advanced Vocabulary - Page 3

Expand your sophisticated vocabulary with these advanced words that demonstrate intellectual precision and eloquent expression in formal contexts.

Navigation

This is page 3 of 12. Use the navigation below to explore all vocabulary pages.

Word List

Banal

/bəˈnæl/

adjective

So lacking in originality as to be obvious and boring.

"His banal comments added nothing to the intellectual discussion."

Synonyms: mundane, trite, hackneyed

Category: Quality

Bellicose

/ˈbelɪkoʊs/

adjective

Demonstrating aggression and willingness to fight.

"The bellicose rhetoric increased tensions between the nations."

Synonyms: aggressive, combative, warlike

Category: Behavior

Benevolent

/bəˈnevələnt/

adjective

Well-meaning and kindly; serving a charitable rather than profit-making purpose.

"The benevolent donor funded the entire scholarship program."

Synonyms: kind, charitable, philanthropic

Category: Character

Bombastic

/bɑːmˈbæstɪk/

adjective

High-sounding but with little meaning; inflated.

"The politician's bombastic speech failed to address real issues."

Synonyms: pompous, grandiose, pretentious

Category: Communication

Camaraderie

/ˌkæməˈrɑːdəri/

noun

Mutual trust and friendship among people who spend a lot of time together.

"The camaraderie among the team members was evident during the celebration."

Synonyms: fellowship, companionship, solidarity

Category: Relationships

Candor

/ˈkændər/

noun

The quality of being open and honest in expression; frankness.

"I appreciate your candor in discussing this difficult topic."

Synonyms: frankness, honesty, directness

Category: Honesty

Capitulate

/kəˈpɪtʃəleɪt/

verb

To cease to resist an opponent or an unwelcome demand; surrender.

"After hours of negotiation, they finally capitulated to our terms."

Synonyms: surrender, yield, submit

Category: Defeat

Caustic

/ˈkɔːstɪk/

adjective

Sarcastic in a scathing and bitter way.

"Her caustic remarks about the proposal offended several committee members."

Synonyms: sarcastic, biting, corrosive

Category: Criticism

Charlatan

/ˈʃɑːrlətən/

noun

A person falsely claiming to have special knowledge or skill; a fraud.

"The so-called expert was exposed as a charlatan with no real credentials."

Synonyms: fraud, quack, impostor

Category: Deception

Chastise

/tʃæˈstaɪz/

verb

To rebuke or reprimand severely.

"The teacher chastised the student for plagiarizing the essay."

Synonyms: reprimand, scold, censure

Category: Correction

Circumvent

/ˈsɜːrkəmvent/

verb

Find a way around an obstacle; overcome or avoid by ingenuity or stratagem.

"They found a way to circumvent the new regulations legally."

Synonyms: bypass, evade, sidestep

Category: Strategy

Cogent

/ˈkoʊdʒənt/

adjective

Clear, logical, and convincing.

"She presented a cogent argument for changing the policy."

Synonyms: compelling, persuasive, convincing

Category: Logic
